data.text: @p8db8q Trust me, I haven’t forgotten. But that was 15 years ago.
@jtlevy So they realized snubbing Black Panther might be peak OscarsSoWhite, and responded by creating a ghetto for it? Oh dear.
@jtlevy And even there, American Sniper made half a billion bucks.

@studentactivism But some years I also just looked at the list and relied on memory.

Your corrections mean that it's *really* only 2015 that the Academy seems to be  panicking about. Makes it seem even stranger.

@studentactivism Whoops! 

I think I was looking at calendar-year-of-release figures. That's useful for some purposes-- it reduces the effect of the Oscar spike itself, which the Oscars can't care about for ratings-- but it's a problem for Christmas prestige releases.

Maybe a blockbuster like Gravity doesn't inspire the same rooting interest on an audience's part as the Lord of the Rings movies did... or Black Panther might.

Did someone in the Academy have a panicked realization that Black Panther might not get nominated?
/fin

@jtlevy What's your benchmark for "high-grossing"? American Hustle made $250m. In 2007, Arrival and Hidden Figures both broke $200m, and La La Land broke $400m. (And that's just out of the ones I spot-checked.)

No Harry Potter movies, no Hunger Games movies, and (obviously) no superhero movies. Indeed the superhero movies have remarkably few nominations even in FX categories, and even fewer wins. Only FX nominations in recent memory are Heath Ledger (won) & Logan (nom. screenplay).

Another thing, to be blunt, is the absence of movies from franchises. Mad Max: Fury Road was a special case-- but before that you have to go back to Toy Story 3 in 2011. 

And in the last 10-15 years, that cuts off a lot of the blockbusters that audiences were most excited about.

On the other hand, the big-budget nominees don't do as much good for ratings if, by the time of the ceremony, everyone knows that the only viable contenders are things they've never seen. And they know this thanks to both polling members and other the long awards season.

Couple things strike me here. One is that 2015 and 2017 are *really unusual,* and not necessarily reasons to panic. (On the other hand, they're two out of the last four years.) "All art-house indie flicks" really doesn't describe the universe of nominees.
